item.title: Atlantic City Hosts First Black Business Expo to Celebrate Entrepreneurship and Economic Empowerment
item.dc:creator: Ziggy Chau
item.description: Atlantic City will host its first-ever Black Business Expo on Tuesday, August 26, at the All Wars Memorial Building, celebrating entrepreneurship, economic empowerment, and the city’s rich legacy of Black-owned businesses. The free event features a vendor marketplace, live radio broadcast, panel discussions, and the launch of a $500,000 Micro-Business Grant Program for minority, women, and veteran-owned startups.
item.content:encoded:
On Tuesday, August 26th, from 5:00 to 8:00 p.m., the All Wars Memorial Building on Adriatic Avenue will transform into a vibrant hub of innovation, culture, and opportunity as the city presents its first-ever Black Business Expo.

The FREE event, held during National Black Business Month, will spotlight local Black-owned businesses, foster economic empowerment, and connect entrepreneurs with the tools and resources they need to grow and thrive.

‍

A Night of Networking, Storytelling, and Celebration

Vendor Marketplace – Dozens of Black-owned businesses will showcase their products and services in a dedicated exhibition space.

Live Radio Broadcast – We Have Gospel will stream live from the event, hosted by Councilman Kaleem Shabazz and Council President Sporty Randolph. Their show will feature on-site interviews with local entrepreneurs, giving them an even wider platform to share their stories.

‍

Panel Discussions

Atlantic City’s Black Business Legacy – Ralph Hunter Sr., Founder of the African American Heritage Museum of South Jersey, will present an exhibit on the city’s rich history of Black entrepreneurship, with a focus on the thriving Northside business district of the past and the lessons it offers today.

Economic Empowerment and Growth – Dr. John E. Harmon Sr., IOM, Founder, President, and CEO of the African American Chamber of Commerce of New Jersey (AACCNJ), will lead discussions with local entrepreneurs on challenges, opportunities, and the future of business in Atlantic City.

‍

Supporting the Next Generation of Entrepreneurs

The evening will also mark the launch of Atlantic City’s new Micro-Business Grant Program. Earlier this year, Mayor Marty Small Sr. dedicated $500,000 to fund minority-, women-, and veteran-owned startups and expansions. Grant applications will open that night, making the Expo a must-attend event for any entrepreneur seeking funding.

‍

Why You Should Go

This isn’t just an expo , it’s your chance to get in the room where opportunity happens.

  • Exclusive access to grant funding that could kickstart or grow your business
  • Direct connections with influential leaders, peers, and potential customers
  • Inspiration from Atlantic City’s entrepreneurial legacy and a role in shaping its future
  • Unique shopping opportunities from local Black-owned businesses
  • Meaningful conversations about economic empowerment and community growth

Whether you’re an established entrepreneur, just starting out, or simply passionate about supporting local, the Black Business Expo puts you at the center of Atlantic City’s small business revival.

‍

Event Details:

Date: Tuesday, August 26, 2025

Time: 5:00–8:00 p.m.

Location: All Wars Memorial Building, Adriatic Avenue, Atlantic City, NJ

item.title: Atlantic City Seniors Enjoy Fresh Flavors at Muzzarelli Farms Visit
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City Senior Services enjoyed a day filled with fresh flavors and vibrant colors during their visit to Muzzarelli Farms in Vineland, bringing home the finest produce for a night of great meals and shared memories.
item.content:encoded:
The vibrant colors of fresh produce and the inviting aromas of nature’s bounty filled the air as Atlantic City Senior Services took a delightful trip to Muzzarelli Farms and Farm Market in Vineland. This outing gave participants a chance to experience the charm of a local farm while selecting top-quality ingredients for their tables at home.

From the moment the group arrived, they were greeted with warm hospitality and a breathtaking display of seasonal fruits, vegetables, and specialty goods. The market’s abundance of fresh offerings showcased the dedication and care that Muzzarelli Farms puts into their harvest.

Seniors strolled through the aisles, enjoying the sights of colorful produce neatly arranged in baskets and crates. The crisp scent of freshly picked vegetables and the sweet fragrance of ripe fruit created an atmosphere that was both energizing and comforting.

This visit was more than a shopping trip—it was an opportunity to connect with local agriculture, learn about where food comes from, and take home wholesome, flavorful ingredients. Many seniors left with bags full of farm-fresh produce, eager to prepare nutritious meals.

The excursion also gave participants a chance to enjoy each other’s company, sharing recipes and cooking tips inspired by the day’s selections. Conversations flowed easily as the group discussed their favorite dishes to make with the vegetables and fruits they picked up.

Atlantic City Senior Services extended their gratitude to Muzzarelli Farms for their generosity and warm welcome. The farm’s dedication to quality and community left a lasting impression on all who attended.

By the end of the visit, the group returned home with not just delicious ingredients, but also fond memories of a day spent immersed in the beauty and richness of farm life. Atlantic City’s seniors truly would be eating well that night, thanks to the bounty gathered during this trip.

item.title: Atlantic City Seniors Showcase Sweet Skills at Soldiers Home
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Queens of Cookie Decorating, along with Mr. Stan, turned the Soldiers Home into a hub of creativity and sweetness during a royal icing class led by Miss Julia. The event brought seniors together for an afternoon of fun, skill-building, and delicious artistry.
item.content:encoded:
The Queens of Cookie Decorating brought their artistic flair and sweet talents to Soldiers Home, turning the afternoon into a celebration of color, creativity, and camaraderie. This special event, organized by Atlantic City Senior Services, transformed an ordinary day into a memorable gathering filled with laughter, learning, and delicious treats.

Participants, including the always cheerful Mr. Stan, embraced the opportunity to explore the art of royal icing. Guided by the skilled and enthusiastic Miss Julia, the group learned techniques that turned plain cookies into edible works of art. From delicate piping to colorful designs, the tables were filled with creations that reflected the personality and creativity of each participant.

‍

The room buzzed with conversation and shared stories as cookies took shape. For many, the event wasn’t just about the decorating—it was about connecting with others, trying something new, and taking pride in learning a skill they could share with friends and family.

Miss Julia’s class provided more than just instructions. She offered encouragement, shared tips from her own experience, and made sure every participant left with not only a box of beautifully decorated cookies but also the confidence to create more at home.

The Soldiers Home setting offered the perfect backdrop for this gathering, combining comfort, community, and creativity. Tables were arranged to foster collaboration, and the scent of freshly baked cookies made the space feel warm and inviting.

‍

This cookie decorating day also reflected Atlantic City Senior Services’ ongoing commitment to creating opportunities for seniors to stay active, engaged, and socially connected. Through events like these, they ensure that seniors have fun and fulfilling activities to look forward to.

The event concluded with smiles all around, as participants proudly displayed their creations and sampled their handiwork. For the Queens of Cookie Decorating and Mr. Stan, it was a day of learning, laughter, and sweet success.

item.title: Atlantic City's Maine Avenue Promenade Officially Opens to the Public

item.description: The City of Atlantic City officially opened the Maine Avenue Promenade, offering breathtaking views, fresh ocean air, and a safe, scenic walkway for all to enjoy. This project marked another step in the city’s mission to improve public spaces and community life.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City proudly unveiled its beautiful new Maine Avenue Promenade, offering residents and visitors a scenic waterfront experience. The newly completed walkway provided stunning views of the water, the fresh ocean air, and a safe space to enjoy the outdoors.

Stretching along the waterfront, the promenade quickly became a favorite spot for those who wanted to stroll, jog, or simply relax while taking in the sights and sounds of the shore. Its wide, well-maintained path and thoughtful design encouraged both active lifestyles and peaceful leisure moments.

Community members and city officials celebrated the project’s completion, highlighting the promenade’s role in improving public spaces and encouraging healthy, outdoor recreation. The area also served as a picturesque location for photography, quiet reflection, and social gatherings.

The Maine Avenue Promenade project was part of the city’s ongoing commitment to revitalization and beautification efforts, enhancing both the appeal and accessibility of Atlantic City’s waterfront.

Residents were encouraged to explore the new walkway and experience firsthand the charm it brought to the neighborhood. Many shared their appreciation for the addition, noting that it created a welcoming environment for all ages.

item.title: Atlantic City Responders Contained Massive Three-Alarm Fire at New Jersey Avenue School
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City’s first responders, alongside neighboring agencies, successfully contained a massive three-alarm fire at the unoccupied New Jersey Avenue School. No injuries were reported, and the fire was brought under control after hours of dedicated effort.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City reported that a massive three-alarm fire erupted at the New Jersey Avenue School late in the evening, prompting an immediate and coordinated response from multiple agencies. The Atlantic City Fire Department, joined by the Atlantic City Police Department, EMS, and several neighboring agencies, worked together to battle the flames well into the night. Their swift arrival at the scene and expert handling of the situation prevented the blaze from spreading to nearby buildings, safeguarding the surrounding community.

The building, which had been unoccupied at the time of the incident, was slated for demolition, meaning there were no students, faculty, or staff inside. While the absence of occupants was a relief, the scale and intensity of the fire posed a significant challenge to the crews on site. Firefighters employed strategic measures to contain the flames, using both ground and aerial operations to bring the situation under control.

As the hours passed, the tireless efforts of the first responders paid off. By the early morning, the fire was declared under control, and officials confirmed that there were no injuries to either civilians or emergency personnel. This outcome was a testament to the training, dedication, and resilience of the men and women on the front lines.

The operation underscored the importance of inter-agency collaboration during emergencies. Neighboring fire departments and emergency units provided critical reinforcement, offering additional manpower, equipment, and logistical assistance that allowed the Atlantic City teams to sustain their efforts throughout the night. Every individual involved played a vital role in the successful containment of the fire, from those directing traffic to the firefighters battling flames in hazardous conditions.

City officials extended heartfelt gratitude to all brave men and women who risked their safety to protect lives and property. Their courage, skill, and commitment to service stood as a reminder of the extraordinary work done by first responders every day, often without recognition. The incident at the New Jersey Avenue School demonstrated not only the dangers they face but also the unwavering determination they bring to every call.

In the aftermath, authorities began their investigation into the cause of the blaze, while crews remained on-site to monitor for potential flare-ups. The community, though shaken by the dramatic event, expressed overwhelming appreciation for the coordinated and professional response that prevented what could have been a far greater tragedy.

‍

Photo Credit: City of Atlantic City

item.title: Community Came Together for Summer Dance Classes at Brown’s Park
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributor
item.description: This August, Midtown Atlantic City CDC hosted a lively series of Summer Dance Classes at Brown’s Park, led by AC Soul Line Dancer Tiffani Drinks. The weekly gatherings brought residents together for music, movement, and community connection.
item.content:encoded:
This past August, the Midtown Atlantic City CDC brought movement, music, and connection to the heart of the community with a series of Summer Dance Classes at Brown’s Park. Held every Thursday evening at 6 PM, the program offered residents a chance to enjoy the warm summer nights in a fun and energetic way.

The classes were led by AC Soul Line Dancer Tiffani Drinks, whose engaging style and enthusiasm inspired participants of all ages to step out onto the dance floor. Each week, neighbors gathered to learn new steps, improve their rhythm, and simply enjoy each other’s company in a welcoming and inclusive space.

Brown’s Park served as the perfect backdrop for the weekly sessions, providing an open-air setting that encouraged both movement and mingling. Families, friends, and even passersby joined in the fun, creating a lively and joyful atmosphere throughout the park.

Participants didn’t need prior dance experience to join — the sessions were open to everyone, from beginners to seasoned dancers. The goal was simple: to get the community moving, smiling, and spending quality time together.

In addition to learning line dancing techniques, attendees experienced the health benefits of regular physical activity, from improved coordination to increased energy. The program also highlighted the value of outdoor gatherings, especially in fostering stronger neighborhood connections.

The final class of the month wrapped up with heartfelt thanks from Midtown Atlantic City CDC and Tiffani Drinks to everyone who attended and made the series a success. Their appreciation extended to the volunteers and staff who helped make each session possible.

The Summer Dance Classes were more than just a recreational activity — they were a celebration of community spirit. By bringing people together in a positive, uplifting environment, Midtown Atlantic City CDC demonstrated the power of local initiatives to enrich lives and strengthen bonds.

Through music, movement, and togetherness, the program added another memorable chapter to the story of Brown’s Park as a place where Atlantic City residents can come together, connect, and create lasting memories.

The series concluded with an open invitation for residents to look forward to future community events that promote health, joy, and unity.

‍

item.title: Center City Deli Honored for Decades of Service in Atlantic City
item.dc:creator: Grea Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City honored Center City Deli with the Midtown Atlantic City CDC Community Impact Award for decades of serving hearty meals, fostering connections, and becoming a beloved gathering place for generations. The recognition was part of the city’s Keep It Local campaign celebrating small businesses that strengthen the community.
item.content:encoded:
In Atlantic City, community isn’t just a concept — it’s something you can see, feel, and even taste. For generations, Center City Deli has been a place where neighbors gather, meals are shared, and friendships are built. Recently, the City of Atlantic City celebrated this enduring spirit by honoring the deli with the Midtown Atlantic City CDC Community Impact Award.

The recognition was part of the City’s “Keep It Local” campaign, led by the Economic Development division under the Planning & Development Department, which shines a spotlight on small businesses that help define the heart and soul of the city.

More Than Just a Deli
For decades, Center City Deli has been serving hearty, no-frills meals that keep locals coming back. From breakfast classics to filling lunches and dinners, the deli has built its reputation not just on its menu, but on the way it treats every customer like family. Owner Theo Dababneh and his team know their customers by name — often their children and grandchildren, too — creating a welcoming space where food and friendship go hand in hand.

A Local Institution
The award recognized Center City Deli not only for its longevity, but also for its role in bringing neighbors together. It’s the kind of place where a simple meal can turn into a long conversation, where regulars stop by for both the food and the familiar faces.

“Our customers came on a regular basis. We knew their names, even their kids, their grandkids — we knew all of them,” said Dababneh. “We felt very honored. We got something back for giving to the people, the community — it was nice.”

Why Atlantic City Thrives
Small businesses like Center City Deli are part of what makes Atlantic City a great place to live and work. They reflect the city’s resilience, its cultural diversity, and its commitment to looking out for one another. When residents support local businesses, they’re not just buying a meal or a service — they’re investing in their own community’s future.

‍

A City for Neighbors
The “Keep It Local” campaign is a reminder that Atlantic City’s greatest strength lies in its people. From family-owned delis to neighborhood shops, these businesses are the threads that weave together the city’s identity.

Living in Atlantic City means having access to more than world-famous beaches and entertainment. It means being part of a community where small businesses thrive, neighbors know each other’s names, and traditions are passed down from one generation to the next.

A Place to Call Home
As Atlantic City continues to grow, its commitment to celebrating and supporting local businesses ensures that it remains not just a destination, but a place where people can build a life. Whether you’re working in the city, raising a family, or simply enjoying its vibrant neighborhoods, Atlantic City offers opportunities to connect, belong, and succeed.

The recognition of Center City Deli was more than just an award — it was a celebration of the connections, memories, and shared experiences that make Atlantic City a place where community is always on the menu..

‍

item.title: Atlantic City Celebrated National Lighthouse Day at the Absecon Lighthouse
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City marked National Lighthouse Day with a community celebration at the Absecon Lighthouse, New Jersey’s tallest and the third tallest in the nation. Guests climbed the 228 steps, enjoyed festival activities, and celebrated one of the city’s most treasured landmarks.
item.content:encoded:
In Atlantic City, summer isn’t just about beaches and boardwalks — it’s also a season for celebrating the city’s history, culture, and community pride. Each year, the City of Atlantic City marks National Lighthouse Day by honoring one of its most treasured landmarks — the Absecon Lighthouse.

Standing as New Jersey’s tallest lighthouse and the third tallest in the nation, the Absecon Lighthouse has been a guiding light for more than a century. Its towering presence serves as both a historic monument and a living reminder of the city’s maritime heritage.

A Celebration for All Ages
During the celebration, residents and visitors are invited to climb the 228 steps to the top, where sweeping views of the city and the Atlantic Ocean offer a breathtaking reward. The climb is more than just a physical challenge — it’s an opportunity to step back in time and imagine the lighthouse’s role in guiding sailors to safety.

The National Lighthouse Day Festival is designed to be a community event where families, history enthusiasts, and first-time visitors can come together. With activities, entertainment, and educational programs, it’s a day that blends fun with learning, making it especially memorable for children.

A Landmark That Unites the Community
For many, the Absecon Lighthouse is more than a tourist attraction. It’s a gathering place — a space where locals connect with their city’s past while enjoying the beauty of the present. Events like this highlight the importance of preserving historic landmarks so they can continue to inspire future generations.

Why Atlantic City Is a Great Place to Live and Work

‍
Celebrations like National Lighthouse Day are part of what makes Atlantic City a strong and vibrant community. The city invests not only in its future but also in honoring and preserving its heritage. Here, residents enjoy a blend of modern opportunities and rich history — a balance that makes Atlantic City a unique place to live, work, and grow.

From historic treasures like the Absecon Lighthouse to new investments in neighborhoods, parks, and public spaces, Atlantic City continues to build a community that values both its people and its places.

A City in Motion

‍
Atlantic City’s commitment to community engagement, cultural preservation, and year-round activities shows that it’s more than a summer destination. It’s a place where history stands tall, opportunities are always on the horizon, and residents take pride in the city they call home.

item.title: Atlantic City's Public Works' Upgraded Toolbox
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City strengthened its Department of Public Works fleet with brand-new vehicles, boosting efficiency, safety, and service for the community. The upgrades included specialized trucks for electrical work, sanitation, stormwater management, and year-round maintenance.
item.content:encoded:
In Atlantic City, summer is more than sunshine and ocean breezes, it’s also a time when the city moves forward. This year, the City of Atlantic City demonstrated its ongoing commitment to residents by adding brand-new vehicles to the Department of Public Works fleet, ensuring services remain efficient, reliable, and ready to meet community needs year-round.

With these new additions, the city has strengthened its ability to deliver essential public services. Whether it’s keeping streets clean, maintaining infrastructure, or responding quickly to seasonal demands, the expanded fleet helps ensure that Atlantic City runs smoothly for everyone who calls it home.

Building the Tools for Better Service
Among the upgrades is a high-reach bucket truck for electrical work, enabling crews to handle repairs and maintenance more quickly and safely. The city also added large and small rear-load garbage trucks, boosting sanitation efforts and supporting cleaner neighborhoods from the Boardwalk to the backstreets.

To keep the city prepared for storm season, stormwater vactor trucks now help maintain catch basins and prevent flooding. And with a universal hook-lift truck equipped for multiple tasks — from snow plowing in winter to leaf collection in autumn — Atlantic City is better equipped for every season.

A Year-Round Commitment to Quality of Life
Each vehicle serves a specific purpose, but together they represent a bigger vision: a city that invests in the tools needed to care for its people and places. It’s about more than machinery — it’s about keeping Atlantic City a cleaner, safer, and more welcoming place for residents, businesses, and visitors.

Why Atlantic City Is a Great Place to Live and Work
Investments like this reflect the spirit of Atlantic City — a community that takes pride in maintaining its neighborhoods, supporting its workforce, and creating an environment where opportunity thrives. From modernized public works equipment to ongoing improvements in housing, parks, and public spaces, the city is building a future where people can live well and work with purpose.

A City in Motion
Just as the tides keep moving, Atlantic City continues to grow and adapt. The upgraded fleet is one more way the city is working to provide dependable services, protect quality of life, and make sure that whether you live here, work here, or visit, you experience the best of what the community has to offer.

item.title: Atlantic City Secures Additional $750K for Fire Station 2 Interior Preservation
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City has secured an additional $750,000 African American Civil Rights Grant to preserve the interior of the 103-year-old Fire Station 2, just as exterior restoration nears completion. This funding builds on previous efforts to protect and restore the historic site’s structural integrity and cultural significance.
item.content:encoded:
Preserving History, Investing in Community: Fire Station 2 Restoration Moves Forward in Atlantic City

‍

In Atlantic City, honoring the past is part of building the future. The City of Atlantic City has secured new funding to take preservation efforts even further on the exterior restoration of the historic Fire Station 2,

Thanks to a second $750,000 African American Civil Rights Grant, the City of Atlantic City will begin a new phase of work in Spring 2026 — this time focused on the interior restoration of the 103-year-old structure located at Indiana and Baltic Avenues. The project will bring modern upgrades to this legacy building, while preserving the elements that give it cultural and architectural significance.

A City That Honors Its History

This restoration project is about more than brick and mortar. Fire Station 2 is a landmark that reflects the deep roots and contributions of the African American community in Atlantic City. It is a building that tells a story — one the city is committed to preserving.

Earlier this year, the City of Atlantic City received a $750,000 New Jersey Historic Trust Grant, also earmarked for interior preservation. Together, the two new grants will restore historic finishes, expand kitchen facilities, and improve dormitory areas — all while modernizing the station’s HVAC, electrical, and plumbing systems.

‍

A City That Protects What Matters

This new phase builds on previous progress. The City of Atlantic City had already secured $1.5 million in grants to restore the building’s exterior, which had suffered from water infiltration, cracking, and aging repairs. Over the past year, all three roofs were replaced, masonry was repointed, and wall flashing was installed to prevent future damage.

With the exterior work scheduled to be completed by the end of 2025, the city is staying focused on its goal: to preserve a vital piece of public infrastructure while protecting the heritage it represents.

‍

Why Atlantic City Is a Great Community

Restoring Fire Station 2 is just one example of how Atlantic City invests in spaces that matter — places where history, community service, and civic pride come together. It’s part of a broader commitment to revitalization that blends historic preservation with progress.

Whether it's restoring a 100-year-old firehouse, launching youth employment programs, or improving recreational spaces, Atlantic City is a place that values its past while building for the future.

A City to Live. A City to Work.

From public safety to public history, Atlantic City is creating a cityscape where families, workers, and future generations can thrive. With every grant secured and every restoration completed, the city sends a clear message: our story matters — and we’re preserving it with purpose.

‍

item.title: Atlantic City’s National Night Out Connects First Responders and Families
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City came together for a memorable evening at National Night Out 2025, celebrating unity, safety, and appreciation for our law enforcement and first responders. The event showcased the power of community partnerships and public service.
item.content:encoded:
In Atlantic City, summer is more than just a season of sunshine, it’s a time for neighbors to connect, families to make memories, and the entire city to honor those who keep our community safe. Through events like National Night Out, Atlantic City continues to show what makes it a strong and united place to live, work, and grow.

Each year, National Night Out brings together residents, first responders, and community partners for an evening of celebration and connection. From music and food to games and educational activities, the event creates space for people of all ages to engage with those who protect and serve—building relationships rooted in trust and respect.

A City That Honors Service
Led by the City of Atlantic City and supported by dedicated partners like the Atlantic City Police Department, Atlantic City Professional Firefighters, Atlantic City Office of Emergency Management, and organizations such as Atlantic City PBA Local #24, NJ FMBA Local 8, and Atlantic City Police Foundation, the event is a heartfelt tribute to the brave men and women who serve on the front lines every day.

More Than an Event—It’s a Statement
National Night Out is about community. It’s about showing that public safety starts with strong relationships and mutual understanding. Events like these remind residents that their voice matters and that they play a role in shaping a safer, more inclusive Atlantic City.

‍

A Tradition of Unity
Whether it's kids high-fiving firefighters, families chatting with police officers, or seniors enjoying music with friends, the energy of National Night Out reflects the values that define Atlantic City: respect, resilience, and community pride.

Why Atlantic City?
Atlantic City is more than a destination—it’s a place where people look out for one another. It’s a city that believes in partnerships, that celebrates diversity, and that shows up when it matters most. From summer events to youth programs, civic engagement is alive and thriving here.

A City to Live and Work In
The heart of Atlantic City beats strongest when we come together. Whether you're raising a family, starting a business, serving the public, or simply enjoying a night out in your neighborhood, Atlantic City continues to prove it's a city where you can truly live, work, and thrive.

As another successful National Night Out reminds us, community doesn’t just happen—it’s built, one conversation, one connection, and one event at a time.

item.title: Atlantic City NFL FLAG Wraps Up an Unforgettable 2025 Season
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City officially wrapped up the 2025 NFL FLAG season, celebrating a summer of teamwork, sportsmanship, and unforgettable moments at Pop Lloyd Stadium. Local youth gave it their all each week, showing heart and hustle in every game.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City proudly closed out another action-packed summer as the NFL FLAG program officially wrapped up its 2025 season. Hosted at the historic Pop Lloyd Stadium, the season brought together youth from across the city for weeks of fun, growth, and athletic development.

Organized by Atlantic City Recreation, the program emphasized more than just competition. Week after week, young players demonstrated teamwork, sportsmanship, and determination as they hit the field and gave it their all.

Each game day was filled with excitement as families and community members gathered in the stands to cheer on the athletes. The field became more than just a place to play—it became a space where confidence was built, friendships were formed, and values were instilled.

Throughout the season, coaches and mentors helped players understand the fundamentals of the game while encouraging them to grow as leaders both on and off the field. These lessons will stay with them long after the final whistle.

Whether it was a first touchdown, a key interception, or just a great defensive stop, every young athlete had a chance to shine. Their dedication and spirit reminded the community of the importance of youth sports in shaping future success.

The NFL FLAG program continues to be a vital part of Atlantic City’s summer offerings, providing a structured and engaging environment for local youth to stay active and learn life skills.

As the 2025 season came to a close, it left behind a collection of memories, highlight plays, and proud moments for players, parents, and coaches alike.

item.title: Atlantic City Youth Leave Their Mark Through Public Art and STEAM Innovation
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: In Atlantic City, public art has become a tool for youth empowerment and education. The STEAM Dreams mural at Levine Staller stands as a symbol of creativity, coding, and the boundless potential of young people in our city.
item.content:encoded:
In Atlantic City, summer isn't only a time for fun in the sun—it's also a season of creativity, learning, and community expression. Through the city's investment in youth engagement and the arts, public spaces have become platforms for empowerment and education. One standout example is the STEAM Dreams mural at Levine Staller, a vibrant collaboration between the Atlantic City Arts Foundation, acclaimed muralist Layqa Nuna Yawar, and the youth of the Boys & Girls Club of Atlantic City.

Inspiring the Next Generation Through STEAM
This mural was more than a public art installation—it was a message to young people across Atlantic City: your ideas matter. Completed as part of Apple’s 2020 initiative to expand coding education in over a dozen cities, STEAM Dreams celebrated the launch of Atlantic City’s Design Lab and two STEAM Labs at local Boys & Girls Club locations. These labs gave youth access to hands-on programs in creativity, technology, and career development, showing them how science and art can intersect to open doors for the future.

A New Era of Learning
By combining Science, Technology, Engineering, the Arts, and Mathematics, the mural reflected the evolving approach to education that gives students the tools to succeed beyond the classroom. Known as STEAM, this model encourages problem-solving, emotional intelligence, and the kind of imagination that powers innovation.

Public Art with Purpose
What made this project truly special was the collaborative process. The mural was co-designed with local youth, ensuring that their voices were part of the creative journey. For many of these students, it was their first opportunity to see their ideas realized on a large scale, turning a downtown wall into a beacon of possibility for the entire community.

A Place to Live, to Work, to Create
Atlantic City continues to grow as a place where young people don’t just participate—they lead. Whether through art, employment programs, or education initiatives, the city is investing in the full potential of its youth. It’s a city where kids can code, students can paint their dreams, and families can gather to witness it all.

Why Atlantic City?
Because Atlantic City believes in its people. Through partnerships with organizations like the Atlantic City Arts Foundation, the Boys & Girls Club, and support from groups like Levine Staller, Senator Gormley, AC Devco, and Chelsea EDC, the city is transforming lives—one creative opportunity at a time.

This is the power of community in action. This is Atlantic City.

‍

item.title: Summer on Stage: Atlantic City Schools Celebrate Talent Through Visual and Performing Arts
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City COntributors
item.description: The Atlantic City Public Schools District celebrated the end of summer school with a series of inspiring Visual and Performing Arts productions. Students across the city showcased their talent, creativity, and teamwork through musicals that left their audiences smiling.
item.content:encoded:
The Atlantic City Public Schools District brought down the curtain on a season of creativity and connection with its Visual and Performing Arts (VPA) Summer School Productions. On Wednesday, July 30, 2025, schools across the district celebrated student talent with live performances that reflected hard work, teamwork, and artistic growth. From Broadway tributes to jungle tales and rock anthems, each school’s show reflected the unique energy and dedication of its students and staff.

Superintendent Dr. La’Quetta S. Small praised the district’s young performers, educators, and families for bringing these productions to life. “Through music, storytelling, and live performance, our students embraced important lessons about courage, friendship, and self-belief. They have inspired us all to celebrate our differences and support one another as we grow.”

At Brighton Avenue School, students performed Broadway Beat, a tribute to the magic of Broadway featuring numbers from Annie, Wicked, Grease, and more. According to Principal Jason Grimes, “They did a phenomenal job,” with all grade levels—even kindergarten—joining in the fun.

Chelsea Heights School rocked the stage with Rock and Roll Forever, a jukebox-style musical that paid tribute to music legends of the past. Principal James Knox highlighted how much the students love VPA, noting, “A lot of famous people got their start on school stages.”

Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. School Complex and New York Avenue School united for Pirates 2: The Hidden Treasure, a playful sequel filled with inclusion, humor, and catchy tunes. Their collaboration emphasized how performing arts can help students connect across school boundaries.

At Pennsylvania Avenue School and Uptown School Complex, students charmed the audience with 101 Dalmatians Kids, showcasing themes of bravery, family, and teamwork. VPA Directors Nycole Lyles Belton and John Howard Jr. praised the students for exceeding expectations in both acting and singing.

Sovereign Avenue School presented two shows: Goldie Locks and the Three Bears for younger students and Character Matters for grades three through seven. These productions highlighted student leadership, values education, and the transformation of students into confident performers.

Texas Avenue School delivered Goal, an inspiring musical centered on soccer, where the students reminded the audience about the value of perseverance, teamwork, and dreams. Principal Lena Gil noted the energy and dedication shown during the limited rehearsal period.

Richmond Avenue School brought the summer season to a vibrant close with Welcome to the Jungle, a musical about embracing self-worth, friendship, and diversity. Principal Shontai Harris acknowledged how the VPA program helped shy students find their voices on stage.

Kawania Durand, Teacher Coordinator for Title One programs, emphasized the deep educational value of the arts. “The arts infuse our lives with meaning on nearly all levels. They inspire creative and critical thinking and encourage acceptance of diversity,” she said. “And they have the magical ability to turn bashful students into full-out performers.”

Through these spirited productions, the Atlantic City Public Schools VPA program proved once again that the arts are a powerful tool for growth, expression, and community. This summer, students didn’t just learn lines and choreography—they discovered the joy of telling stories together.

item.title: Gilchrist Restaurant Honored with Resiliency Award by the City of Atlantic City
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City has recognized Gilchrist Restaurant with the Resiliency Award for its decades-long service to the community, honoring the restaurant’s role in preserving tradition, creating jobs, and offering a welcoming space for residents and visitors alike.
item.content:encoded:
In Atlantic City, small businesses are more than storefronts — they are family legacies, community staples, and drivers of economic strength. As part of the city’s ongoing Keep It Local campaign, the City of Atlantic City recently honored a beloved business that exemplifies endurance, quality, and community spirit: Gilchrist Restaurant, recipient of this year’s Resiliency Award.

Spearheaded by the city’s Department of Planning & Development, the Keep It Local campaign shines a spotlight on the essential role small businesses play in shaping Atlantic City’s identity and future. From iconic eateries to corner stores, these businesses are a reflection of the city’s character, history, and commitment to growth.

A Story of Resilience and Roots

Founded in 1946, Gilchrist Restaurant has long been a favorite for locals and visitors alike. With locations on both sides of town, it has become a go-to spot to start the day with a hearty breakfast or gather for a comforting lunch. Now owned by Denise Stamat and Michael Barham, Gilchrist continues to serve up the same casual charm and rich tradition that has kept it at the heart of the community for generations.

Receiving the Resiliency Award was more than just a recognition — it was a reflection of what it means to endure. “It’s an honor to be recognized,” said Barham. “For our family really — for family that isn’t here — that we’ve still been able to keep it going so long and be successful and grow.”

Why Atlantic City Believes in Local

This recognition is part of a broader mission by the City of Atlantic City to uplift and empower its local entrepreneurs. Whether through grants, promotions, or public events, the city is making it clear: small business matters. These are the places where jobs are created, traditions are upheld, and dreams take root.

From longstanding institutions like Gilchrist to emerging start-ups, Atlantic City remains committed to creating an environment where business owners feel supported and where residents can take pride in shopping and dining locally.

A City Where Businesses Thrive

What sets Atlantic City apart is its resilience — not just in its people, but in its places. Every small business that withstands the test of time contributes to a deeper sense of place, purpose, and pride. And every recognition like the Resiliency Award is a reminder that success here is measured not just by profits, but by perseverance.

So, why live in Atlantic City?

Because it’s a city that believes in its own — a place where you can launch a business, grow a legacy, and find a community that shows up for you.

Whether it’s award-winning restaurants, family-run shops, or new ideas taking shape in old buildings, Atlantic City is a place to live, to work, and to thrive — one small business at a time.

For more about local business highlights and how to support the community, visit the City of Atlantic City’s “Keep It Local” campaign page.

item.title: Richmond Avenue Students Soared with Hands-On STEM Drone Program
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Students at Richmond Avenue School soared beyond textbooks this summer as they built and programmed drones through a dynamic STEM Summer Program. From hands-on assembly to flight simulations, the initiative inspired problem-solving, teamwork, and future-ready skills in Atlantic City's next generation of innovators.
item.content:encoded:
Atlantic City Students Take Flight with Hands-On Drone Program

In Atlantic City, summer learning means more than books and classrooms — it means rising to new heights. Through an innovative STEM Drone Program at Richmond Avenue School, local students spent the season not only building drones, but also building confidence, collaboration, and career dreams.

This program was part of the city's broader effort to provide youth with immersive, future-ready experiences. Each summer, Atlantic City’s public schools continue to push learning beyond the traditional model — and this drone program proved just how powerful that can be.

Learning by Doing

Instead of passively absorbing facts, students rolled up their sleeves and assembled commercial-grade drones from the ground up. Using Rub iQ kits, they learned to wire motors, install cameras, and troubleshoot complicated circuitry. It was engineering in action — tactile, technical, and teamwork-driven.

“These are the most complex drones we’ve ever used,” said instructor Nabi Chowdhury, who guided the students through every challenge. “They learned to problem-solve and adapt, even when tools didn’t work as expected.”

From flight simulators to hands-on assembly, every step of the program pushed students to think critically and work together. For some, the learning curve was steep — and that’s exactly what made it meaningful.

Real-World Skills, Real Impact

Whether improvising with pliers to solve a mechanical issue or working through communication breakdowns as a team, students learned that success isn’t just about following instructions. It’s about curiosity, perseverance, and trust in one another.

Principal Shontai Harris encouraged students to connect their learning to real-world possibilities. “Drones are used in roofing, insurance, public safety — all kinds of industries,” Harris said. “What they’re doing here is engineering, and it’s valuable for so many career paths.”

Students also explored flight simulators to build the coordination and decision-making skills needed for real drone piloting. The experience sparked new ideas, new interests, and new connections between classmates from different backgrounds.

A Community That Lifts Its Youth

When technical issues arose due to GPS signal limitations downtown, students quickly adapted — switching to older drones and planning a future launch from a nearby beach. For educators like Allison Clark, the takeaway was clear: “They were taken out of their comfort zones and rose to the challenge.”

The program showed that when students are trusted with real tools and real responsibility, they respond with creativity, grit, and pride.

Why Atlantic City?

This STEM Drone Program is just one example of how Atlantic City continues to invest in its youth — not only in summer but year-round. From hands-on STEM camps and creative arts programs to job training and scholarships, the city is building pathways to opportunity.

Programs like this remind us why Atlantic City is more than a destination — it’s a community. A place where young people can see themselves reflected in their schools, their neighborhoods, and their future.

It’s a city where students don’t just learn — they launch.

‍

Adding Bella Condominiums to the Senior Services network reflects Atlantic City’s proactive approach to outreach. Rather than waiting for seniors to come to the city, the city goes directly to them, a model that continues to strengthen trust and increase participation.

Under the leadership of Mayor Marty Small, Sr. and the City of Atlantic City, these initiatives aim to ensure that every senior, regardless of where they live, has access to vital resources, opportunities, and community support.

The Atlantic City Senior Services team continues to grow its footprint in neighborhoods across the city, working closely with building managers and residents alike to customize offerings that reflect each community’s needs.

As Bella Condominiums officially joins the Senior Family, the City of Atlantic City reaffirms its dedication to creating a city where residents of all ages can thrive, together.

item.title: Atlantic City's Dolphin Field Revitalized with $1.33M Green Acres Grant
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City completed major improvements to Dolphin Field thanks to a $1.33 million grant from the Green Acres Program. Upgrades include new turf, lighting, fencing, and ADA accessibility, marking another step in the Small Administration’s commitment to better recreational facilities.
item.content:encoded:
A Stronger Field, A Stronger Future

In Atlantic City, parks and playfields are more than green spaces, they are gathering places, practice grounds, and community anchors. And now, thanks to a $1.33 million Green Acres Program grant, Dolphin Field has been fully revitalized, ready to serve the next generation of athletes, families, and fans.

Led by Mayor Marty Small, Sr., the transformation of Dolphin Field reflects the City of Atlantic City’s ongoing investment in public recreation. From the new turf and upgraded lighting, to renovated locker rooms, improved ADA accessibility, and modern fencing and landscaping, this project was designed to enhance both performance and safety — and to give residents a facility they can be proud of.

Where Community Comes to Play

More than just a sports field, Dolphin Field has long been a home for local football players, especially the Atlantic City Dolphins organization. When Mayor Small first announced the project alongside players, coaches, and supporters, it marked a renewed commitment to the role of sports in building confidence, teamwork, and belonging.

With these upgrades now completed, the space is once again ready to support weekend games, afterschool practices, and community gatherings. It’s a place where kids can chase dreams and families can cheer them on.

Local Support, Lasting Impact

The project would not have been possible without generous community partnerships. Local developer and Hard Rock Atlantic City owner Joe Jingoli previously contributed a new scoreboard and funding for earlier improvements, which remain an important part of the field today. The city has also applied for an additional $250,000 grant from the NFL to further enhance the facility.

This collaborative spirit between city leaders, local donors, and residents is what makes Atlantic City more than just a destination. It’s a place where people invest in each other.

A City Built on Momentum

Dolphin Field is just one piece of a much larger movement under the Small Administration. Across Atlantic City, playgrounds are being modernized, parks are being beautified, and public spaces are being made more inclusive. These projects are not just about infrastructure, but about identity. It's about building a city where people want to live, work, and grow.

For families, it means safer, more welcoming spaces. For youth, it means more opportunity to stay active, connected, and inspired.

Why Live in Atlantic City?

Because Atlantic City believes in its people. Whether it’s summer youth jobs, scholarships, cultural programming, or upgraded sports fields, this city continues to invest in the things that make communities thrive.

This summer, as residents enjoy the beach and boardwalk, they’ll also see the results of thoughtful, community-focused leadership at play — on fields like the Dolphin Field, and in neighborhoods all across the city.

For updates on more projects making a difference, visit the “Your Tax Dollars at Work.”

item.title: Atlantic City Charges Ahead with New Public Electric Vehicles Stations at City Hall
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City powered up six new EV charging stations at City Hall, offering public access to fast and reliable electric vehicle charging. This move marked a bold step toward a cleaner, greener transportation future for residents and visitors alike.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City officially expanded its commitment to sustainability by installing six new EV charging stations at City Hall, located at 1301 Bacharach Boulevard. These chargers became publicly available and provided local drivers with a convenient, eco-friendly option to power their vehicles in the heart of the city.

The newly installed stations included four DC Fast Chargers and two Level 2 Chargers, all of which could be accessed via the ChargePoint app. Designed to accommodate a variety of electric vehicles, these stations were introduced to support Atlantic City's growing green infrastructure and help combat transportation-related emissions.

Transportation is one of the leading contributors to greenhouse gas emissions in urban areas. By offering modern charging solutions in a central location, the city demonstrated a proactive approach to environmental responsibility and urban innovation.

The chargers operated under standard charging rates, easily viewable within the app, and served as an important public resource for both residents and visitors who rely on electric transportation.

This milestone aligned with Atlantic City’s broader environmental goals, including reducing carbon emissions, encouraging cleaner energy adoption, and improving air quality. The charging stations represented not just technological progress, but also a cultural shift toward more sustainable urban living.

City leadership emphasized that these efforts were part of a long-term commitment to enhancing green transportation infrastructure and providing the tools needed for residents to make cleaner driving choices.

The installation of these EV chargers also complemented other sustainability initiatives already underway in Atlantic City, reflecting a unified strategy for environmental resilience.

By making these stations publicly available, the city took a meaningful step toward accessibility, equity, and environmental justice in clean energy.

With the addition of these EV chargers, the City of Atlantic City reaffirmed its dedication to building a cleaner, greener future, one charge at a time.

item.title: Atlantic City Beach Patrol Shines at Home in Lifeguard Classic
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Atlantic City Beach Patrol Race Team earned a strong third-place tie during the Atlantic City Lifeguard Classic, held right on their home turf at Albany Avenue Beach. With standout performances across multiple events, ACBP once again demonstrated excellence, teamwork, and pride in representing their city.
item.content:encoded:
The Atlantic City Beach Patrol (ACBP) Race Team delivered an impressive performance during the Atlantic City Lifeguard Classic, securing a third-place tie at their home beach on Albany Avenue. The competition, held in North Amityville, New York, showcased some of the region’s most skilled and dedicated lifeguards, and ACBP rose to the occasion with determination and strength.

In the Surf Dash, team members Emmett Kane, Andrew Gillman, Sabrine Ghazaz, and Ty Costabile led the way, capturing a first-place finish. Their speed and coordination set the tone for the rest of the competition and energized the entire squad.

The Doubles Row team of Vince Granese and Nick Guidara also climbed the podium with a third-place victory. Their precision and endurance in the surf demonstrated the high level of training and teamwork ACBP athletes bring to every event.

In the Doubles Rescue Race, Tom Muskett and John Swift tackled the surf with confidence and grit, representing the squad with honor in one of the most physically demanding contests of the day.

The team also put forth a strong effort in the Doubles Relay, with Michelle Burwell, Nick Guider, Julianna Granese, and Vince Granese working seamlessly together to complete the event with determination and skill.

In the Swim/Paddle Relay, Adam Schreiner, Adam Bailey, Harrison Gillman, and Mo Levin showcased versatility and stamina, further contributing to the team's overall standing.

Finally, John Swift represented ACBP in the Singles Row, rounding out the day’s races with a determined solo performance.

These results highlighted the exceptional training and camaraderie within the Atlantic City Beach Patrol, especially when competing on familiar sands. The team’s ability to tie for third among elite competitors from across the region is a proud moment for both the patrol and the community it protects.

With every competition, the ACBP Race Team continues to build on a legacy of excellence, safety, and sportsmanship. Their strong showing at the Lifeguard Classic is just one of many moments where Atlantic City’s finest lifeguards have proven their mettle in and out of the water.

item.title: Uptown Skate Park Launches a New Era for Atlantic City Community
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The grand opening of Uptown Skate Park marked more than just a new destination for skaters, it signaled Atlantic City’s continued investment in youth, community spaces, and inclusive summer opportunities where everyone can grow, move, and thrive.
item.content:encoded:
In Atlantic City, summer is more than just sand and surf, it’s about creating space for possibility. That spirit continues this season with the highly anticipated Grand Opening of Uptown Skate Park, a bold new addition to the city’s growing youth recreation landscape.

Located at Melrose and Massachusetts Avenues, the Uptown Skate Park is more than a concrete playground, it’s a symbol of Atlantic City’s commitment to building places where young people can move freely, build confidence, and connect with their community.

The effort has been championed by multiple local partners, including the Inlet Community Development Corporation and grassroots skate advocates like SkateAC, all working together to turn an underutilized lot into a destination for connection and movement.  Beneath the excitement lies something deeper: a shared vision for a more vibrant, inclusive, and youth-centered Atlantic City.

‍

‍

‍
‍

Why Atlantic City Builds for the Next Generation

‍
Skateboarding is more than a sport, it’s a culture rooted in creativity, resilience, and belonging. That’s why Atlantic City made it a priority to develop this space in the Uptown neighborhood, giving young residents a safe and exciting place to gather, practice, and grow.

Whether a beginner landing their first ollie or a seasoned skater competing in the trick contest, the park is designed to welcome everyone. And like all of the city's youth programs—from employment and leadership initiatives to arts mentorship and public safety academies, this project reflects a bigger goal: to meet young people where they are and support them in becoming who they want to be.

‍A Skatepark. A Signal. A Start.

‍
What makes the Uptown Skate Park special isn’t just the ramps or rails, it’s what they represent. By investing in community-driven projects like this, Atlantic City continues to show its deep belief in the power of public space to spark personal transformation.

And as youth carve their way across the park’s smooth surfaces this summer, they’re not just practicing tricks, they’re building confidence, forming friendships, and strengthening their ties to the community they call home.

Why Atlantic City?

‍
With the opening of Uptown Skate Park, Atlantic City affirms its place as a city where opportunity lives outside the classroom and off the clock. From Midtown to Inlet, and from Chelsea to the Beach Blocks, the city is working to ensure that every neighborhood is a place where youth can live fully, work purposefully, and grow with pride.

A City in Motion

‍
Skaters, students, artists, entrepreneurs, no matter the path, there’s space for everyone in Atlantic City’s future. Through ongoing investment in public amenities, creative programming, and inclusive infrastructure, the city is building not just for today, but for generations to come.

As wheels roll, music plays, and another summer unfolds, one thing is clear: Atlantic City isn’t standing still, it’s rolling forward, one skatepark at a time.

item.title: Texas Avenue School Renovation Marks Bold Step With Renovations
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Texas Avenue School underwent major renovations, including bold new paintwork, modern locker upgrades, and a turf playground installation. The improvements marked a new era for the historic building, aligning with the district’s larger mission to modernize school facilities across Atlantic City.
item.content:encoded:
The Texas Avenue School in Atlantic City underwent a significant transformation, marking the beginning of a new chapter for the historic institution. As part of the Atlantic City School District’s broader investment in modernizing educational facilities, the school received extensive updates that aimed to rejuvenate both its appearance and functionality.

Visible from the moment one approached the building, the most striking change was the new paint job, featuring bold red accents that reflected the school’s official colors. The fresh coat of paint revitalized both the exterior and hallways, giving the building a vibrant, contemporary look while honoring its long-standing identity.

Beyond the surface, the school addressed deeper infrastructure needs. The third floor saw the removal of outdated lockers, some of which had been in place for decades. These were replaced with sleek, modern units, offering students more secure and accessible storage solutions. This improvement aligned with the district’s goal to create safer and more student-friendly environments.

Outdoors, the school added a new turf playground, providing a durable, safe, and visually appealing surface for students to enjoy physical activity. This upgrade was especially impactful in encouraging active play while reducing maintenance needs.

Principal Lina Gil expressed pride in the project, emphasizing its broader effect on the school culture. “These projects have a significant impact on staff and students by enhancing the physical environment and sense of pride in the school community,” Gil said. Her words reflected a shared sentiment among faculty and families who welcomed the updates as a sign of renewed commitment to quality education.

The upgrades extended to future plans as well. A brand-new kitchen was in development to improve food service operations and support more efficient meal preparation. This improvement would not only enhance daily logistics but also contribute to better nutritional experiences for students.

The Texas Avenue School renovation was part of a larger district-wide initiative. Across Atlantic City, multiple schools received summer upgrades including HVAC system replacements, window installations, and classroom equipment enhancements, ensuring that students returned in the fall to facilities better suited for 21st-century learning.

As the first day of school approaches, Texas Avenue School stands as a powerful example of how thoughtful investment in infrastructure could support educational success. What had once been a century-old structure now felt like a beacon of renewal and readiness.

item.title: Atlantic City Hosts Successful First-Ever Community Care Family Fun Day

item.title: Atlantic City Recognizes Pancho’s for Two Decades of Community Impact
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City honored Pancho’s Mexican Taqueria with the Ducktown AC Community Impact Award for its 20 years of service and cultural influence in the Ducktown neighborhood. Through the Keep It Local campaign, the city recognized Pancho’s lasting role in strengthening community ties and supporting local pride.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City, through its ongoing “Keep It Local” campaign, proudly celebrated the contributions of small businesses that serve as the heart and soul of the community. Spearheaded by the Economic Development division under the Planning & Development Department, the initiative highlighted businesses that have not only thrived economically but have also made a deep and lasting impact on the lives of residents. Among the honorees, one establishment stood out for its enduring presence and community influence—Pancho’s Mexican Taqueria.

The beloved Ducktown restaurant was honored with the Ducktown AC Community Impact Award, a recognition bestowed on businesses that embody community values, local pride, and long-term commitment to service. The award ceremony celebrated the legacy and contributions of Pancho’s, which has served the Ducktown neighborhood faithfully since 2005.

Founded by Fabiola Sanchez, Pancho’s Mexican Taqueria began as a humble yet passionate effort to bring authentic Mexican cuisine to the Atlantic City community. Over the years, it grew into more than just a restaurant—it became a place where families gathered, neighbors connected, and memories were made. Now under the leadership of Fabiola’s son, Joshua Cruz, the restaurant has continued to uphold its core values while evolving with the times.

From its flavorful tacos and savory burritos to its warm customer service and community engagement, Pancho’s has become a staple in the neighborhood, especially among locals who appreciate its consistency and cultural authenticity. The restaurant’s influence has gone beyond the menu—it has participated in local events, supported neighborhood causes, and helped foster a sense of belonging within Ducktown.

In accepting the Community Impact Award, Joshua Cruz expressed deep appreciation for the recognition, stating, "It’s been a long 20 years for all of us and to receive such an award is an honor." He went on to emphasize the restaurant’s commitment to staying true to its roots while continuing to serve the community with pride. "We’re very grateful to be acknowledged this way. Ducktown is our home, and the people here have supported us from day one," he shared.

The “Keep It Local” campaign is part of Atlantic City’s broader strategy to strengthen local commerce and promote sustainable neighborhood growth. By spotlighting businesses like Pancho’s, the city aims to inspire a culture of local appreciation and investment, encouraging residents and visitors alike to support homegrown establishments that reinvest in the community.

The recognition of Pancho’s Mexican Taqueria is not just about longevity—it is about impact. The restaurant’s ability to thrive for two decades in a dynamic, ever-changing cityscape reflects its adaptability, strong leadership, and unwavering dedication to quality. From first-time customers to loyal patrons, Pancho’s has created lasting impressions and continues to be a beacon of neighborhood pride.

As the city looks to the future, it is clear that small businesses will continue to play a critical role in shaping the identity and economic vitality of Atlantic City. item.title: Bounce Out the Stigma Brings Inclusive Basketball and Empowerment to Atlantic City Youth
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Bounce Out the Stigma basketball camp brought together Atlantic City youth of all abilities for a day of skills, fun, and confidence-building. Led by Mighty Mike and supported by Atlantic City Recreation, the event proved that inclusion and play go hand in hand.
item.content:encoded:
Basketball, Belonging, and Big Wins: Inclusion Takes the Court in Atlantic City

In Atlantic City, summer means more than sunshine and boardwalk fun—it means opportunity for everyone, including youth with disabilities. Through programs like Bounce Out the Stigma, the city is redefining what inclusive recreation looks like—and why it matters.

Led by national speaker and coach Mike “Mighty Mike” Simmel, the Bounce Out the Stigma Basketball Clinic welcomed children of all abilities for a day of empowerment, movement, and teamwork. Designed for youth facing challenges such as autism, ADHD, and other developmental conditions, the camp offered more than basketball—it delivered confidence.

‍A City That Makes Inclusion a Priority

‍
Held in partnership with Atlantic City Recreation, the event was part of a broader effort to create programming where every child feels seen, safe, and celebrated. From learning basic drills to trying out Mighty Mike’s signature basketball tricks, participants explored new skills in a setting that was upbeat, accessible, and filled with encouragement.

As Mighty Mike shared with the group, the day was about more than games—it was about “drill skills and thrills” that strengthen both the body and spirit. Students were challenged to stretch beyond their comfort zones while building friendships, boosting motor skills, and unlocking their potential through play.

Why Atlantic City Believes in Its Youth

‍
According to Eric Brembert of Atlantic City Recreation, the city’s long-term vision includes making recreation accessible for all—whether through inclusive camps like this one or by expanding offerings citywide. In 2025, the city announced plans to add free swimming lessons, with a special focus on underserved neighborhoods like Island 48 blocks, where water safety education is critically needed.

The Bounce Out the Stigma clinic was more than just a one-day event—it was part of a growing movement in Atlantic City to create programming where inclusion isn’t an afterthought, but a foundation. Through collaboration, leadership, and community support, the city is opening doors for every resident to engage, grow, and thrive.

Real Confidence. Real Impact.

‍
What sets Atlantic City apart is the intention behind its programs. Leaders aren’t simply organizing events—they’re building platforms for transformation. Whether it’s a job training session, a leadership camp, or a basketball court filled with kids learning to believe in themselves, the message is the same: you belong here.

And when a child with sensory challenges feels safe enough to shoot a basket—or when a first-time participant runs to join their team with excitement—that’s the kind of impact that lasts.

Why Atlantic City?

‍
Programs like Bounce Out the Stigma represent why Atlantic City is more than just a vacation destination—it’s a community where families of all kinds can live fully, grow confidently, and build meaningful connections. Here, summer is a season of belonging, and every neighborhood is part of the movement to make opportunity accessible to all.

A City in Motion

‍
With inclusive programming, visionary partnerships, and a commitment to youth empowerment, Atlantic City is not just responding to its community’s needs—it’s anticipating them. As leaders continue to expand access across all ages and abilities, the city is proving that when everyone has a place to play, everyone wins.

This summer and every summer, Atlantic City continues to show the world what inclusion looks like in action—one child, one game, and one joyful moment at a time.

item.title: Atlantic City Fire Department’s Youth Explorer Program Sparks Interest in Lifesaving Careers

item.description: The Atlantic City Fire Department Youth Explorer Program gave local youth a unique introduction to emergency response and water safety, partnering with the Beach Patrol to deliver skills and confidence that could spark future careers. With tripled enrollment and repeat participants, the program proved its lasting impact.
item.content:encoded:
Where Courage Meets Curiosity: Atlantic City’s Youth Explorer Program Ignites a Passion for Public Safety

‍

In Atlantic City, summer is more than just a season—it’s a platform for purpose. Through programs like the Youth Explorer Program hosted by the Atlantic City Fire Department, local youth are gaining more than experience—they’re gaining direction.

Now in its third year, the Youth Explorer Program continued to thrive as it offered students a hands-on introduction to emergency services, lifesaving skills, and real-world leadership training. It’s become one of the city’s most sought-after summer experiences, reflecting a broader mission: to equip Atlantic City’s next generation with the tools they need to lead.

A Community That Invests in the Future

‍
Led by Deputy Chief Dwayne Brock, a 26-year veteran of the fire department, the program gave participants access to skills often reserved for professionals—CPR training, rescue simulations, water safety techniques, and more. In partnership with the Atlantic City Beach Patrol, students also received practical instruction in junior lifeguard duties, including rowing and surf awareness.

But beyond the drills and demonstrations, the Youth Explorer Program offered something deeper: confidence. For many young people, it was their first experience being part of a structured team environment that demanded discipline and rewarded curiosity. They left not only with certifications and safety pamphlets—but with purpose.

‍

Why Atlantic City Believes in Its Youth

‍
Every summer, more students are signing up—and coming back. With enrollment tripling since the program went digital, the Fire Department has welcomed a growing number of participants each year, many of whom have joined the program multiple times. This recurring interest speaks volumes: young people in Atlantic City are eager for challenge, mentorship, and meaningful opportunity.

As Deputy Chief Brock emphasized, early exposure to career pathways—and the professionals who guide them—can change a life’s trajectory. The program’s returning students are proof that when youth are inspired, encouraged, and believed in, they rise.

Building Confidence Through Service

‍
The Explorer Program isn’t just about firefighting. It’s about community. Through mock emergency scenarios and firehouse tours, students got an inside look at what it means to serve—and protect—a city. They asked questions. They practiced. And most importantly, they discovered their own capacity to lead in moments that matter.

For some, this experience will spark a lifelong passion for public safety. For others, it may be their first taste of teamwork, courage, and personal accountability. Either way, they leave better prepared for whatever future they

Why Atlantic City?

‍
Programs like the Youth Explorer Program are part of what makes Atlantic City such a powerful place to live, work, and grow. The city doesn’t just entertain—it empowers. From free youth initiatives and leadership camps to arts mentorship and workforce training, Atlantic City creates space for young people to discover who they are and where they’re headed.

A City That Moves with Purpose

‍
Every summer, while others may be vacationing, Atlantic City’s youth are in motion—learning, building, and becoming. With the support of mentors like Deputy Chief Brock and the Atlantic City Fire Department, the next generation is rising, equipped with more than skills—they’re armed with confidence, civic pride, and a drive to serve.

And that’s what makes Atlantic City not just a destination, but a community where young leaders are forged—every summer, one spark at a time.

item.title: From Camp to Career: Atlantic City Youth Trained for the Future in Junior Police Academy
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The AC’s Junior Police Academy challenged and empowered 11- and 12-year-olds through discipline, fitness, and leadership, creating lasting impact beyond summer. With alumni now serving as officers, the program proved it was more than a camp—it was a foundation for life.
item.content:encoded:
Discipline. Leadership. Purpose.

‍
Every summer, while some cities slow down, Atlantic City powers up with programs designed to shape its future. One of the most transformative examples is the Junior Police Academy—a two-week experience that gives local youth more than just a taste of law enforcement. It gives them the tools to lead.

Hosted by the Atlantic City Police Department, the Junior Police Academy is open to rising fifth and sixth graders, ages 11 and 12. It’s a structured yet inspiring summer journey that blends discipline, physical fitness, character-building, and teamwork, all wrapped in a supportive and motivating environment.

Where Futures Begin

‍
Each year, dozens of students enroll not knowing what to expect. Some are nervous about the physical challenges. Others have never spoken in front of a group. But by the end of the program, they’re standing taller—more confident, more focused, and more connected to the idea that greatness comes through hard work.

‍

From military drills and public speaking to locker inspections and leadership elections, every part of the academy is intentional. It’s not about creating future officers—it’s about preparing future leaders. Students are encouraged to push past fear, to speak up, and to support one another as teammates. They also learn the importance of physical wellness, mental toughness, and resilience—skills they’ll carry far beyond the classroom.

A City That Believes in Its Youth

‍
Like many youth-focused initiatives in Atlantic City, the Junior Police Academy is rooted in the belief that structure and support can change lives. Officers involved in the program mentor students not just for two weeks, but for life. That mentorship has already made a generational impact: three past academy graduates are now full-time police officers—two in Atlantic City, one in Ocean City.

After a summer of drills, training, and education (with a little fun along the way), this year’s class celebrated their graduation—marking the close of another season of growth and the beginning of something much bigger.

Why Atlantic City?

‍
The Junior Police Academy is one of several summer programs that reflect what makes Atlantic City a great community—not just for entertainment or vacation, but to live, to work, and to grow. These opportunities are part of a larger citywide commitment to creating spaces where young people are seen, supported, and inspired.

From the Mayor’s scholarship initiatives and Summer Youth Employment Program, to neighborhood events and creative mentorship programs, Atlantic City is investing in its next generation with purpose.

A City in Motion

‍
Every summer, the city takes bold steps forward. Through public safety programs, arts and culture initiatives, educational investments, and youth development opportunities, Atlantic City continues to prove what locals already know: this is a city that believes in its people—especially its young ones.

Whether it’s on the boardwalk, at a community center, or standing in line at morning formation—opportunity lives here.
